paragraph.docTitle:
Flavonoid biosynthesis in
Dianthus caryophyllus
L. is early regulated during interaction with
Fusarium oxysporum
f. sp. dianthi

subSection.paragraph:
Harold Duban Ardila
a, *

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Resistance

Fusarium oxysporum Flavonoid
biosynthesis Carnation
Targeted metabolite profiling mRNA levels
A B S T R A C T

Rooted cuttings from two carnation (
Dianthus caryophyllus
L.) cultivars showing contrasting responses to the vascular wilt caused by
Fusarium oxysporum
f. sp. dianthi ( Fod ) were inoculated with this phytopathogen, and some of the biochemical responses associated with flavonoid biosynthesis were investigated in the roots. The resistant cultivar (‘
Golem
’) showed a significant increase in the levels of phenolic and flavonoid compounds at 48–96 h post-inoculation (hpi) ( α = 0.05 ). LC-MS-based analysis indicated that the flavonoids mainly included flavanol-type glycosides, especially quercetin and kaempferol aglycones. Quantification of the mRNA levels of genes encoding CHS ( Chalcone Synthase ), CHI ( Chalcone Isomerase ), FLS ( Flavonol Synthase ), and the transcription factor MYB11 by using reverse transcription quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) indicated that the resistant cultivar exhibited higher expression levels of these genes and, therefore, showed more flavonoid accumulation at 96 hpi. The differences in the temporal regulation of the assessed variables during infection support the idea that the early expression of enzymes of the flavonoid biosynthesis pathway in carnation roots is linked to a resistance response to the hemibiotrophic pathogen Fod race 2. The present experimental approach is the first report describing the molecular mechanisms underlying flavonoid biosynthesis in carnation roots during their interaction with Fod .
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: hdardilab@unal.edu.co (H.D. Ardila).

et al., 2020). In this regard, although the relationship between the presence and content of some endogenous specialized metabolites and the resistance level against Fod has been previously determined in several studies, recent studies on this topic are limited. The information available until now indicates that Fod -resistant carnation cultivars produce several antifungal compounds, such as anthranilate derivatives (e. g., dianthalexins) and phenolics (e.g., benzoic acids and flavonoids), against the pathogenic infection ( Curir et al, 1996 , 2003 ; Niemann et al., 1992 ). However, accumulation of antifungal metabolites in carnation tissues depends on the plant part involved, since nitrogenous compounds usually accumulate in stems ( Baayen and Niemann, 1989 ), whereas phenolics appear to be preferably accumulated in roots ( Higuera and Montes, 1996 ).

The presence of antifungal flavonoids against Fod in carnation has attracted the attention of researchers because these compounds have been isolated from healthy and inoculated plant parts and tissues of resistant carnation cultivars. A previous study reported that inoculated plants of the Fod -resistant ‘Novada ’ carnation cultivar exhibited increased accumulation of kaempferide 3- O -[2 G -β- D- glucopyranosyl]- β- rutinoside in both stems and roots for 10 days after inoculation ( Curir et al, 2001 , 2005 ). The anti- Fod fungitoxic effect of this constitutive flavonol glycoside in this cultivar has also been reported ( Curir et al., 2005 ). Other Fod -resistant carnation cultivars (i.e., ‘ Roland ’) yielded fungitoxic flavonoids such as quercetin 3- O -α- L- arabinopyranosyl-(1 → 6)-β- D- glucopyranoside (peltatoside) and 3,5,7,2 ′ -tetrahydroxyflavone (datiscetin) from healthy and inoculated in vitro -generated calli and parent plants ( Curir et al., 2003 ). Other flavonoids such as apigenin 6, 8-di- C -β- D- glucopyranoside, kaempferol 3- O -β- D- glucopyranosyl-(1 → 2)- O -[α- L- rhamnopyranosyl-(1 → 6)]-β- D- glucopyranoside, and kaempferol 3- O -[α- L- rhamnopyranosyl-(1 → 6)]-β- D- glucopyranoside have also been described and quantified in several carnation cultivars ( Galeotti et al., 2008a ). Additionally, roots of resistant cultivars were found to contain higher levels of flavonoids than those of susceptible cultivars ( Ardila et al., 2013 ).

Activation of the biosynthetic pathway for a specific metabolite at the early phase of pathogen infection is a key point influencing the role of these pathways in resistance ( Ahuja et al., 2012 ; Treutter, 2005 ). In carnation, the current evidence for flavonoid biosynthesis associated with Fod resistance includes the differential expression of genes encoding proteins involved in the biosynthetic pathway. Thus, the differential constitutive expression of these two flavonoid biosynthesis enzymes (i.e., CHS and CHI) in the roots of cuttings from susceptible and resistant cultivars ( Ardila et al., 2013 ), as well as the isolation of specific fungitoxic flavonoids from the roots of resistant cultivars ( Curir et al, 2001 , 2003 , 2005 ), have been previously explored. However, holistic evaluations of the differential accumulation of these compounds and molecular evidence for the dynamics of flavonoid biosynthesis in carnation roots in response to Fod inoculation are limited. Therefore, as a part of our research on carnation– Fod interaction, we investigated the differential flavonoid accumulation responses and the expression of biosynthetic genes during the interaction with this pathogen in carnation roots, and then evaluated the differences between resistant/susceptible and constitutive/inoculated pairs. The results confirmed the importance of flavonoid-related production and accumulation within those roles in the resistance of carnation against Fod.

The effects of Fod infection on flavonoid biosynthesis in carnation were investigated under a three-phase study, whose workflow is outlined in Fig. 1 . The study phases consisted of several experimental and analytical steps. Phase 1 involved an assessment of the phenotypic responses of two carnation cultivars to Fod infection on the basis of their differential responses against this pathogen in the field in order to classify them into resistant and susceptible cultivars. Once these cultivar-dependent responses were verified, phase II was oriented to design an in vivo Fod -inoculation assay to evaluate the early responses of these carnation cultivars by sampling roots at different post-inoculation times. In phase III, the collected roots (per time, cultivar and Fod -inoculated or non-inoculated condition) were extracted and the chemical and transcriptional changes caused by Fod presence were finally examined.

paragraph.emphasis: 2.1. Differential Fod resistance levels of the carnation cultivars used in the in vivo assay

document.paragraph:
The differential pathogen responses of the two carnation cultivars (‘
Golem
’ and ‘ Mizuki ’) were examined in a 7-week post-inoculation in vivo assay. Plants of these cultivars were rigorously scrutinized each week during the experiment and, if symptoms of vascular wilting were detected, these plants were registered at those time points and the severity index (SI) was calculated (see Experimental section). Disease evolution (expressed as SI over time) exhibited differences among cultivars and between inoculated and control plants ( Fig. 2 ). ‘ Mizuki ’ began to show symptoms of the disease at the fourth week (SI = 0.1), while ‘
Golem
’ showed symptoms from the sixth week, indicating differences in the disease progression in these cultivars. Finally, ‘ Mizuki ’ reached an SI value of 0.7 at the seventh week, which was significantly higher (
P < 0.05
) than that of ‘
Golem
’ (SI = 0.3). The symptoms of the carnation cultivar ‘
Golem
’ are consistent with the previously reported quantitative Fod resistance trait, wherein some symptoms of wilting may appear under a high inoculum pressure ( Baayen et al., 1988 ; Ben-Yephet and Shtienberg, 1997 ; Soto-Sedano et al., 2012 ). Visual analysis of cross-sections of the stems of the inoculated carnation plants shows degradation of the vascular tissue in ‘ Mizuki ’, and an evident browning process in the vascular xylematic tissues of ‘
Golem
’, as reported previously in resistant genotypes ( Baayen et al., 1986 ). The contrasting phenotypic responses of these two carnation cultivars against Fod was confirmed from this in vivo experiment and comparable to the field observations. Therefore, under these experimental conditions, these cultivars were classified as ‘
Golem
’ resistant cultivar (GRC) and ‘ Mizuki ’ susceptible cultivar (MSC). These cultivars were then used in the subsequent in vivo assays to evaluate the early-stage chemical and transcriptional changes.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 1. Three-phase workflow performed in this study. Each colored segment comprises the general steps (in boxes) adopted in each study phase. hpi = hours postinoculation. TPC = Total phenolic content. TFC = Total flavonoid content.

Fig. 2. Vascular wilt severity, expressed as severity index (SI), during the 7- week in vivo assay. Each data point is expressed as mean SI ± standard error of the mean (SEM) as vertical bars (n = 3). Different letter marking each data point indicates significant differences for each post-inoculation time examined according to Tukey test (P < 0.05). Carnation cultivars: GRC = ‘
Golem
’ resistant cultivar; MSC = ‘ Mizuki ’ susceptible cultivar.

emphasis.heading: 2.2. Chemical variations in carnation roots during the Fod-inoculation in
vivo assay

subSection.paragraph: Both carnation cultivars with contrasting responses to Fod infection (i.e., GRC and MSC ) were employed in a subsequent 96-h Fod -inoculation in vivo assay to explore the variations of the phenolic and flavonoid contents as well as the liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC-MS)-derived flavonoid profiles of carnation roots at the early phase in response to Fod presence, according to our workflow ( Fig. 1 ).

emphasis.heading: 2.2.1. Total phenolic and flavonoid contents in carnation roots during Fod
infection

subSection.paragraph: The changes in total phenolic content (TPC) and total flavonoid content (TFC) constitute a first-line approach to determine the early changes occurring in flavonoid biosynthesis ( Ardila et al., 2013 ). During the 96-h in vivo assay, carnation plants effectively exhibited variations in TPC and TFC at different levels. For the TPC of the two cultivars with and without Fod inoculation, values were found to be in the range of 50–210 μg of gallic acid equivalents (GAE) per g fresh weight (fw) of plant material ( Fig. 3a ). However, the constitutive TPC values showed significant differences between cultivars; therefore, GRC yielded an average value of 100 μg GAE/g fw, whereas MSC afforded 50 μg GAE/g fw. These results coincided with the values reported for nine carnation cultivars grown and commercialized in Colombia with contrasting levels of resistance to Fod ( Ardila et al., 2013 ).

On the other hand, the TFC also showed some changes in the carnation plants evaluated in this study ( Fig. 3b ). TFC values were found to be in the range of 40–120 μg of catechin equivalents (CE) per g of fresh plant material ( Fig. 3 ). Constitutive TFC expression showed similar behavior as that of TPC. GRC showed higher average TFC values (i.e., 70 mg CE/gtw), which were significantly different from those of MSC (i.e., 40 CE/gtw). These results also coincide with the findings of previous studies in other carnation cultivars ( Ardila et al., 2013 ), in which enhanced flavonoid contents were related to resistance against Fod ( Curir et al, 2001 , 2003 , 2005 ; Galeotti et al., 2008a ). In fact, variations in the flavonoid contents of resistant cultivars and different tissues have been also reported for pathosystems involving
Fusarium
pathogens ( Arfaoui et al., 2007 ; Dihazi et al., 2011 ; Lorenc-Kukuła et al., 2007 ; Morkunas et al., 2011 ; Sekhon et al., 2006 ). In addition, inoculation with Fod race 2 causes a significant increase (
P
< 0.05
) in both TPC and TFC values at 96 hpi in GRC roots, since such elevations were not observed in the respective controls, nor in the inoculated MSC , at the same time (i.e., 96 hpi) ( Fig. 3a ). However, the TFC of inoculated GRC roots exhibited a significant difference at 48 hpi in comparison to the non-inoculated plants. The increase in TFC after inoculation may be associated with the role of these metabolites in the regulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) ( Agati et al., 2020 ; Dumanovi´c et al., 2020), whose mechanism has been reported to be important for preventing activation of the necrotrophic pathogen phase ( Mierziak et al., 2014 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. (a) Total Phenolic Content (TPC) and (b) Total Flavonoid Content (TFC) of carnation roots at early times during the 96-h Fod -inoculation in vivo assay. TPC expressed as micrograms of gallic acid equivalents per gram of fresh weight (μg CE/100 g fw). TFC expressed as micrograms of catechin equivalents per gram of fresh weight (μg CE/g fw). Each data point is expressed as mean values ± standard error of the mean (SEM) as vertical bars (n = 3). Different letter indicates significant differences for each post-inoculation time examined according to Tukey test (P < 0.05). Carnation cultivars: GRC = ‘
Golem
’ resistant cultivar; MSC = ‘ Mizuki ’ susceptible cultivar.

emphasis.heading: 2.2.2. Chemical variability through targeted metabolic profiling of
carnation roots during Fod-inoculation in vivo assay

subSection.paragraph: Variations in the chemical composition of the 54 raw extracts from carnation roots were also investigated by means of targeted metabolic profiling in order to expand the flavonoid characterization and distribution beyond TFC during Fod inoculation, and select the statistically top-ranked constitutively expressed and induced flavonoids in the carnation resistance response. LC-MS profiles were processed and the MS-derived features were then recovered from the raw profiles and labelled with the respective retention time–mass/charge ratio (rt/ m/z ) pairs. In total, 1235 negative ion mode-derived features were identified and subsequently filtered to compile specifically flavonoid-like metabolites according to the typical flavonoid bands I and II (i.e., 270–295 and 310–350 nm , respectively) in the UV spectra. After this filtering process, 96 filtered features (i.e., flavonoids) from 54 observations (i.e., samples) were gathered into a dataset to create a feature intensity table (FIT) and used to explore and analyze the metabolite changes under supervised statistics. The most important features ranked and selected by the statistical analysis were annotated at MSI level 2 ( Schymanski et al., 2014 ) by using accurate mass and diagnostic MS fragment evidence. The rest of the features were annotated at MSI levels 3–4 or remained unannotated. The most statistically important annotated features exhibited quasimolecular ions above m/z 500 and triggered fragment ions at m/z 285, 301, and 315, indicating the presence of kaempferol, quercetin, and methylquercetin flavonols as aglycones, which was confirmed by the UV maximum absorptions at ca. 340 and 280 nm (i.e., bands I and II, respectively) for flavonols. Additionally, the presence of fragment ions at m/z 162, 146, 132 loses, which are the typical sugar fragments of glycosides for hexose (glucose), pentose (arabinose), and deoxyhexose (rhamnose) residues, respectively, and the deduced presence of ester substitutions (such as acetyl, galloyl, synapyl, feruroyl, and malyl) led to the compound annotation presented in Table 1 . In this regard, some authors suggested that the flavonoid glycosylation mediated by uridine diphosphate glucosyltransferase (UGT) enzymes played a significant role in responses to biotic stresses ( Campos et al., 2019 ; Le Roy et al., 2016 ; Xing et al., 2017 ). However, while the addition of a particular glycosyl group does not directly influence the biological activity, it can indirectly improve other physicochemical properties to facilitate the action, such as transport and targeting ( Le Roy et al., 2016 ).

caption.paragraph: Annotation of top-ranked flavonoid-related features, selected from statistical analyses (PCA, MEBA, PLS-DA) that influenced discrimination between carnation cultivars (constitutive) and Fod -inoculated and non-inoculated carnation plants (induced).

tableNote.paragraph: a Annotation at level 3 of MSI confidence ( Schymanski et al., 2014 ) by diagnostic evidence from UV, accurate mass and MS fragments data; Sugar residues: glc =

glucose, ara = arabinose, rha = rhamnose, glu = glucuronide. b Molecular formula of the annotated compound [M], deduced from the adduct [M-H] - . c Diagnostic fragments observed in the respective HRMS spectra. d Annotated compound at level 4 of MSI confidence by HRMS, whose flavonoid type was deduced from UV spectrum data. PCA = principal component analysis;
MEBA = multivariate empirical bayes approach; PLS-DA = partial-least squares-discriminant analysis.

subSection.paragraph:
2.2.2.1. Metabolic profiling-based analysis of constitutive flavonoids from the roots of carnation cultivars.
An exploratory overview of these constitutive root flavonoids that are potentially relevant in discriminating the non-inoculated carnation cultivars studied herein was initially performed through univariate analysis. A paired fold change (FC) analysis was then conducted to compare the absolute change values between both cultivars for all the evaluated time-points, by using these two global categories as group means (i.e., GRC and MSC , gathering the different sampling times per cultivar) to classify the whole dataset. It was then pre-processed through log transformation and mean-centering (i.e., column-wise normalization) to calculate the ratio between group means. Thus, the number of GRC / MSC pairs with consistent change above or below |2| (as selected threshold) was counted, and the resulting pairs were expressed as log2 scale (FC). The significant features identified by FC analysis are presented in Fig. 4a . The number of significant features per cultivar was found to be 37 for GRC (red dots) and 9 for MSC (blue dots), indicating a global difference in the flavonoid composition between these cultivars. The existence of a higher number of significant flavonoid-related features in GRC can be firstly rationalized due to the genetic differences among GRC and MSC . However, other resistant cultivars were recognized to accumulate higher amounts of some metabolites and even more metabolites than susceptible cultivars, which were related to Fod resistance ( Curir et al, 2001 , 2003 , 2005 ). In addition, as mentioned above, this accumulation may exhibit a time-dependent occurrence ( Ardila et al., 2013 ; Higuera and Montes, 1996 ). Therefore, a principal component analysis (PCA) was performed to evaluate the flavonoid-based chemical differences along sampling times (0–96 h). The resulting three-dimensional (principal component 1 [PC1] vs. PC2 vs. PC3) score plot is presented in Fig. 4b . This score plot showed a particular clustering pattern, representing 81% of the explained variance. The earlier times (0 and 12 h) of both cultivars were grouped to form a single cluster, but the later times (24, 48, and 96 h) were separated among cultivars. MSC exhibited a greater difference than GRC between 24 and 48 h. The highest difference between cultivars was observed at the latest time point (i.e., 96 h), which agreed with the findings for TPC and TFC. The PCA-derived loadings plot revealed four features that influenced the discrimination of these GRC samples collected at later times (see Fig. 4c ). In order to evaluate the performance of these features over time, the dataset was analyzed through a multivariate empirical Bayes approach (MEBA) ( Xia et al., 2011 ). This approach led us to rank the features by the differences in temporal profiles among cultivars according to the Hotelling-T2 values. The most-discriminating features selected by PCA for GRC (i.e., 42.4/579.1371, 61.8/582.1423, 43.1/801.2053, and 63.1/797.2114) were ranked by the highest Hotelling-T2 values ( > 105 ), which indicate that the time-course profiles of these features are more different between GRC and MSC cultivars ( Fig. 4d ). The behavior of these features was found to be different, showing a modest abundance at earlier times but increasing over time to reach the maximum values at 48 or 96 h, and showing a differential constitutive accumulation of these compounds between cultivars. This differential response showed a higher capacity to biosynthesize flavonoids at a constitutive level in the carnation resistant cultivar ‘
Golem
’ during the early times in the in vivo assay, so this fact will provide important insights into carnation plant selection based on discriminatory flavonoids ( Galeotti et al., 2008b ; Maia et al., 2020 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 4. Important features selected by fold-change (FC) analysis, principal component analysis (PCA) and multivariate empirical bayes approach (MEBA) of carnation samples according to the profiles of constitutive flavonoids from both non-inoculated cultivars. (a) Paired FC analysis with threshold |2| of GCR/MSC ratio as comparison type. UV-based filtered features were labelled retention time–mass/charge ratio (rt/ m/z ) pairs. A feature was highlighted as significant if this ratio was above/below threshold. Red dots represent features above the threshold and related to GRC; Blue dots represent features below the threshold and related to MSC. (b) PCA-derived 3D-scores plot (81% of explained variance). Cultivars are differentiated by colors (blue = MSC; red = GRC); Sampling times (in h) are differentiated by shapes (circles = 0 h; squares = 12 h; triangles = 24 h; diamonds = 48 h; octagons = 96 h). GRC samples collected at later times (24, 48, and 96 h) are highlighted with the semi-transparent red ellipse. (c) PCA-derived 3D-loadings plot. Each dot represents a feature and the distribution across the 3D-plot is related to its statistical influence on principal components for discriminating the samples. The most-influencing GCR-related features are highlighted the semi-transparent red ellipse. (d) Time-course profiles of those high-ranked features for GRC. GRC = red time-course; MSC = green time-course. (e) Hotelling-T2-ranked features from MEBA. Autoscaled relative abundances per cultivar according to the heat map colors: red = higher; blue = lower. Bold numbers in parenthesis correspond to the annotated features listed in Table 1. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
Other features were also selected as important variables on the basis of the PCA- and MEBA-derived Hotelling-T2 values ( Fig. 4e ). From these important features, six flavonoids influenced the GRC discrimination maximally, whereas MSC was differentiated by the abundance of four flavonoids. These features showing the highest influence on discrimination of GRC and MSC , annotated at level 3 of MSI confidence as mentioned above, are listed in Table 1 . The annotated, statistically important glycosylated flavonoids 1–9 were found to be particularly related to the flavonol type , except flavone 10 . In particular, flavonol glycosides exhibited a structural trend based on a flavonoid aglycone (quercetin or kaempferol) attached to 1–3 sugar residues with an esterified group, except compounds 2, 3, and 7 . The presence of constitutive flavonols in these cultivars is a part of the metabolic characteristics of this plant species ( Galeotti et al., 2008a , 2008b ), since the distribution of some specific flavonoids at higher amounts in the resistant cultivar would support the hypothesis of their role in resistance ( Ardila et al., 2013 ; Curir et al, 2001 , 2005 ). The most important flavonoids statistically ranked and selected in this study have not been previously described in carnation, except quercetin 3- O -α- L- arabinopyranosyl (1 → 6)-β- D- galactoside, which has the same aglycone and substitution pattern of the top-ranked compound 7 , a quercetin pentosyl-hexoside. The reported flavonol glycoside was previously detected in inter-node explants of ‘ Roland ’ resistant and ‘
Gloriana
’ susceptible carnation cultivars, and it proved to be slightly inhibitory toward the pathogen ( Curir et al., 2003 ). This fact is in agreement with our findings, since the abundance of the glycosylated flavonoid 7 was greater in GRC than in MSC (although it occurred in both cultivars). Therefore, such GRC-abundant flavonoids (i.e., 2 , 5–9 ) are of interest since they may be involved in some role in the resistance against Fod . The antifungal activity of glycosylated flavonoids isolated from carnation has been previously reported. For instance, kaempferol 3- O -β- D- glucopyranosyl (1 → 2)- O -[α- L- rhamnopyranosyl-(1 → 6)]-β- D- glucopyranoside isolated from the ‘
Tirana
’ cultivar exhibited fungitoxic activity against Fod race 2 ( Galeotti et al., 2008a ) and the kaempferide 3- O -[2 G- β- D- glucopyranosyl]-β- rutinoside, a constituent of the carnation cultivar ‘ Novada ’, was postulated to be a phytoanticipin ( Curir et al., 2001 ) with a phytoalexin-like role, considering its levels during pathogen infection ( Curir et al., 2005 ).

2.2.2.2. Metabolic profiling-based analysis of induced flavonoids associated with carnation defense against Fod.
Once resistant and susceptible cultivars were discriminated over time on the basis of constitutive flavonoids, the analysis was oriented to compare the flavonoid composition of Fod -inoculated and non-inoculated plants of both carnation cultivars at different post-inoculation times. Such a comparison was initially accomplished by two-factor clustering using Ward algorithm, whose intuitive visualization as a heat map is presented in Fig. 5a . The factors considered for this clustering were post-inoculation ‘time’ (12, 24, 48, and 96 hpi) and the plant ‘condition’ as primary ordering. In this case, the factor ‘condition’ refers to the combination of each cultivar ( GRC and MSC ) with and without Fod inoculation. Similar to the findings for the analysis of constitutive flavonoids ( Fig. 4a ), during this assay, GRC exhibited more flavonoid-related features with higher intensity than MSC , and 96 hpi also turned out to be the time that yielded the maximal number of higher-intensity features. The findings at 48 hpi also revealed other important features in GRC that were different from those of MSC . Additionally, Fod -inoculated GRC showed meaningful abundance differences from its control (non-inoculated plants), and these features also differed from those of MSC , indicating the induction of distinctive flavonoids between cultivars as a consequence of the Fod infection. Indeed, Ward clustering divided the dataset into two main groups according to the comparative metabolic distribution of each cultivar. However, the number of induced flavonoids in GRC was higher than those induced in MSC (See Fig. 5a ). Therefore, in order to explore the major patterns associated with each factor, an ANOVA-simultaneous component analysis (ASCA) ( Smilde et al., 2005 ) was employed on a flavonoid-filtered FIT dataset. This algorithm first splits the overall data variance into individual variances induced by each factor (i.e., “time” and “condition”), as well as by one interaction (i.e., “time × condition”), and the major variations in each partition are summarized by a PCA applied to individual factors and interaction. The resulting models (see Fig. 5b ) illustrated the score variations associated with the factors “condition” and “time” on the first component, which explained 87.7% and 68.2% of the variation, respectively. The model of the factor “condition” ( Figs. 5b – 1 ) indicated that the highest variations were presented in Fod -inoculated GRC , being oppositely different to that of MSC , as noticed in the previous two-factor clustering. Furthermore, flavonoid induction was more evident in the inoculated GRC in comparison to the control, so the Fod -related response of GRC can be considered to be higher. On the other hand, the “time” factor-related model ( Figs. 5b – 2 ) revealed a time-dependent behavior of the variations. This finding suggested that variations between cultivars and inoculation regarding control is enhanced over time, reaching a statistically important maximum variation at 96 hpi. The “time × condition” interaction-derived submodels on the first component (which explained 41.5% of the variation) confirmed the behavior observed for individual factors, since the highest variations were caused by inoculated GRC ( Figs. 5c – 3 ) and 96 hpi ( Figs. 5c – 1 ) in comparison to the other conditions and times. MSC exhibited decreasing variation, implying a lower flavonoid-related response against Fod, possibly as part of the susceptibility phenotype related to the higher disease progression ( Fig. 2 ). The same interaction scores for the second component (28.2% of variation explained) exhibited a second behavior involving the highest variations at 48 hpi by inoculated GRC , which is in agreement with the enhanced accumulation over time. Under this context, the resistant cultivar exhibited the highest time-course response for flavonoid accumulation caused by Fod inoculation, and 96 hpi appeared to be the time point with the highest response at root level.

To elucidate these findings, a dual comparison between Fod -inoculated and non-inoculated plants of carnation GRC at 96 hpi was carried out to identify the features that influence the discrimination of such a condition. Thus, the ten top-ranked features by an unpaired parametric t -test exhibited four compounds previously related to constitutive levels ( 4 , 5 , 6 , 7 ) and six other flavonoids that were not ranked in the previous analysis related to constitutive metabolites ( 11–16 ) ( Fig. 6a ). Two flavonoids ( 5 , 16 ) were selected to be related to GRC control and the remaining eight top-ranked flavonoids were important for inoculated GRC ( 4 , 7 , 11–15 ); therefore, these last flavonoids were considered to show a possible association with pathogen resistance. Among these compounds, a flavonoid ( 12 ) was annotated at MSI level 4 of confidence since the diagnostic evidence was not useful to clarify a higher annotation level and the type of flavonoid was deduced by the UV bands ( Table 1 ), whereas compounds 11 , 13, and 15 exhibited the same structural pattern as the top-ranked constitutive flavonoids (i.e., an aglycone attached to pentose or hexose residues with an ester substitution), even flavone 14 . On the other hand, three glycosides ( 6 , 7 , 11 ) showed the lowest P-values (-log 10 (raw P-value) > 6), so their fold changes in comparison with the control could be interpreted as indicating that these were the most induced flavonoids by Fod inoculation in the resistant cultivar. Compounds 6–7 (previously found to be as constitutively abundant flavonoids in GRC ) are significantly induced by Fod inoculation, and compound 11 , which was constitutively expressed in lower amounts, is also largely induced. These observations, as well as the classification model performance, were demonstrated and validated by classical receiver operating characteristic ( ROC ) curves under the same dual inoculation comparison ( Fig. 6b ). For these three t -testderived top-ranked flavonoids, the area under the curve (AUC) was found to be 1 with high FC values ( > 2). The mean distribution and optimal cutoffs between Fod -inoculated and non-inoculated group samples were additionally very dissimilar according to the respective box-plots ( Fig. 6b ). The MEBA-derived time-course profiles also confirmed our findings, exhibiting significant abundance increments at 96 hpi for Fod -inoculated GRC roots ( Fig. 6c ). On the findings for constitutive and induced expression, flavonoids 6 (even 4 ) and 11 can be proposed as phytoanticipin and/or phytoalexin-like candidates, respectively, since kaempferol derivatives have exhibited biological activity against Fod ( Curir et al., 2001 ) and other phytopathogens (Gorniak´et al., 2019). However, this hypothesis requires additional studies to demonstrate such a role against this pathogen (e.g., fungitoxic activity). In addition, flavonols can act as antioxidants and can function as direct scavengers of reactive oxygen species (ROS), in addition to their functions in activation of antioxidant enzymes and/or inhibition of oxidases ( Agati et al., 2020 ; Baskar et al., 2018 ), and they are related to resistance against nechotrophic and hemibiotrhophic pathogens ( Dodds and Rathjen, 2010 ; Horbach et al., 2011 ; Kumudini et al., 2018 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Distribution and factor-associated patterns of flavonoid-related features during the in vivo Fod -inoculation assay. (a) Two-factor clustering in the form of heat map ordering by condition (i.e., combinations of GRC/MSC cultivars and Fod -inoculated/non-inoculated (as control) plants) and post-inoculation times (12, 24, 48, 96 hpi). Condition was used for primary ordering. Each colored cell on the map indicates the higher (red) or lower (blue) autoscaled relative abundances. (b) Major patterns identified by ANOVA-simultaneous component analysis (ASCA) associated with condition ( b-1 ) and time ( b-2 ). G + i = inoculated GRC; GC = GRC control; M + i = inoculated MSC; MC = MSC control. (c) Major patterns identified by ASCA associated with two-component factor interaction submodels: interaction ‘condition × time’ scores on the first ( c-1 and c-3 ) and second ( c-2 and c-4 ) components. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

paragraph.emphasis: 2.3. Variations in the transcript levels of genes encoding flavonoid biosynthesis enzymes in carnation roots during the Fod-inoculation in vivo assay

subSection.paragraph: The transcript levels of genes encoding flavonoid biosynthesis enzymes were evaluated by RT-qPCR during the 96-h in vivo Fod -inoculation assay. In this study, inoculation with the pathogen generated a significant increase in mRNA levels of the putative genes encoding CHS, CHI, and FLS enzymes and the TF cMYB ( Fig. 7 ). At the constitutive level (0 hpi), no significant differences were observed in the transcription of the chs and chi genes for two carnation cultivars ( GRC and MSC ) and, in general, chi showed a similar profile to that observed for chs ( Fig. 7a and b ). These results do not completely coincide with the findings reported by Ardila et al. (2013) , who showed that resistant carnation cultivars have higher transcriptional levels than susceptible cultivars. However, the two sets of results cannot be directly compared because the strategy for gene expression quantification differed across the studies, with the previous study using the absolute quantification expressed as transcript copies of each gene by the total RNA extracted. Transcript levels of chs in roots during the pathogen infection did not exhibit differences between the treatments at 12 and 24 hpi, but a significant mRNA level increase at 48 hpi was observed in both cultivars, with the increase being higher in the resistant cultivar ( Fig. 7a ). Additionally, significant differences were only observed in the inoculated roots of GRC at 96 hpi. For the transcript levels of the chi gene, a significant increase in the resistant genotype GRC at 24 and 48 hpi was caused by pathogen inoculation ( Fig. 7b ). The results for the transcriptional levels of these genes ( chs and chi ) at 24 and 48 hpi can be related to the accumulation of flavonoids at 96 hpi for this resistant cultivar ( Figs. 5–6 ). Therefore, the transcriptional increase of the chs and chi genes may be a response possibly associated with pathogen resistance.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 6. Most-important flavonoids from roots of resistant carnation cultivar (GRC) at 96 h post-inoculation (hpi). (a) Top-ranked rt/ m/z features by t -test associated with Fod -inoculated or non-inoculated (control) plants of GRC. The ranking is organized from top to bottom according t -test. Each colored cell on the map the heat map indicates the higher (red) or lower (blue) autoscaled feature intensities. Bold numbers in parenthesis correspond to the annotated features listed in Table 1. (b) Classical receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves of the three top-ranked features comparing Fod -inoculated/control plants of GRC at 96 hpi. Sensitivity on the y-axis; Specificity on the x-axis. Area-under-the-curve (AUC) in blue. Box-plots of the autoscaled intensity of each selected feature between inoculated and control groups within the dataset are presented at left side of each ROC curve. A horizontal red line in box-plots define the optimal cutoff. (c) Time-course profiles of crossvalidated, top-ranked features of GRC. GRC = red time-course; MSC = green time-course. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph: The transcriptional constitutive levels of putative fls ( Dca12008.1 gene) in GRC were found to be significantly higher than those in the susceptible cultivar ( Fig. 7c ). These levels in the Fod -inoculated GRC particularly increased at 24 and 96 hpi in comparison to the control, whereas MSC roots only exhibited a difference between control and inoculated samples at 24 hpi. The higher mRNA levels of fls in the resistant cultivar may be associated with the aforementioned abundance of flavonols ( Hou et al., 2020 ; Li, 2014 ; Ravaglia et al., 2013 ). However, increased transcription of the fls gene was found to occur earlier than those of the chs and chi genes (i.e., from 24 hpi in GRC ), which can be also associated with the accumulation of certain flavonoids at 48 hpi ( Figs. 4–6 ) and an early response through production of flavonols that, due to their antioxidant capacity, would present a quick counteracting effect against the elevated ROS levels caused by the pathogen recognition ( Agati et al., 2020 ).

Regarding transcriptional levels of the putative cmyb11 gene ( Dca2677.1 ) coding for the TF cMYB, both cultivars showed significant differences between the constitutive levels and those derived at 12 hpi and 48 hpi after Fod inoculation. In contrast, no significant differences were observed between the controls and inoculated plants at 24 hpi. Although 48 hpi represents a reasonably prompt response against
Fusarium
pathogens ( Lanubile et al., 2012 ; Liu et al., 2016 ), GRC exhibited an earlier response based on the significant increase in cmyb11 levels at 12 hpi. These results suggest that this Dca26277.1-encoded TF may be involved in the gene regulatory processes for flavonoid biosynthesis. Thus, the joint activation of this gene with other genes coding for TFs of chs , chi , f3h , and fls ( Stracke et al., 2010 ) could be considered as a part of the molecular mechanism related to the polygenic mechanisms against Fod , particularly emphasizing the essential regulatory role of the phenylpropanoid pathway in plant
resistance ( Desmedt et al., 2021 )
.

A Pearson correlation analysis was eventually employed to compare the test flavonoid biosynthesis-related parameters ( Table 2 ). A positive correlation was found between TFC and the transcriptional levels of chs (0.56, α = 0.05 ), as well as the transcriptional levels of chi and chs (0.95, α = 0.05 ) and the mRNA encoding the TF MYB11. Flavonoid biosynthesis in carnation roots can be considered to be a transcriptionally regulated complex process. However, the total content and semiquantitative levels of flavonoids in carnation roots were related to the transcriptional increase in the genes encoding CHI, CHS, and FLS enzymes, which are particularly important for flavonoid accumulation in plants ( Hoang et al., 2015 ; Ma et al., 2014 ). We suggest that the transcriptional activation of the chs , chi , and fls genes is a part of the complex response related to the innate resistance mechanisms for recognizing MAMPs (microbe-associated molecular patterns) conserved in
Fusarium
genus. The changes in the ROS levels caused by pathogen recognition may generate the activation of MYB TFs, which have been reported to be associated with transcriptional activation of flavonoid biosynthesis enzymes ( Ramirez-Prado et al., 2018 ; Zhang et al., 2016 ). It is likely that the increase in H 2 O 2 content during Fod inoculation activates these carnation MYB TFs to increase the transcriptional levels of the genes encoding flavonoid biosynthesis enzymes. Thus, our findings indicate the influence of the protein cMYB11 on flavonoid biosynthesis in carnation roots, consistent with the regulatory role of myb11 over chs and chi genes ( Pandey et al., 2015 ; Patra et al., 2013 ). This fact coincides with the polygenic nature of carnation resistance against race 2 of this pathogen ( Baayen et al., 1991 ; Soto-Sedano et al., 2012 ).

Our findings yielded some insights involving flavonoid biosynthesis in the resistance response against Fod in carnation roots. Pathogen recognition occurred in the early phase, as previously reported for this pathosystem ( Ardila et al., 2014 ). This recognition triggered signaling toward the cellular nucleus and induced increased cmyb gene transcription at 12 hpi ( Fig. 7d ). Elevated protein levels of the cMYB TF enhanced the promoter activity of chi and chs genes and favored the increase in the mRNA levels of these genes at 24 hpi ( Fig. 7a and b ). Higher transcriptional levels of chs and chi led to increased CHI and CHS enzyme activity in the endoplasmic reticulum, where flavonoid biosynthesis occurs ( Agati et al., 2012 ; Petrussa et al., 2013 ). Subsequently, the mRNA level of the fls gene increased at 48 hpi, which, in turn, enhanced the levels of this protein. Glucosyltransferase (GTF) enzymes are estimated to be important during flavonoid synthesis, as previously described, mainly in relation to the accumulation and transport of these compounds ( Zhao and Dixon, 2010 ). Finally, certain acylglycosylated kaempferol-like flavonoids (such as 4 , 6 , 11 ) will accumulate at 96 hpi, mostly in vacuoles ( Zhao, 2015 ). The final localization of the accumulated flavonoids during infection should be in the apoplast, and their action would be related to its antioxidant and/or antifungal activity against Fod ( Agati et al, 2012 , 2020 ; Zaynab et al., 2018 ). In summary, the early phase of flavonoid biosynthesis in both carnation cultivars was perturbed differentially by the presence of Fod , and involved the accumulation of certain flavonols and the temporal transcriptional upregulation of MYB11 TF, CHI, CHS, and FLS enzymes from 12 to 96 hpi. The temporal variations of these components during Fod infection support the events related to the early flavonoid biosynthesis-based response as a resistance trait of carnation against the hemibiotrophic pathogen
Fusarium oxysporum
f. sp. dianthi ( Fod ) race 2.

caption.paragraph: Pearson correlation coefficients between the test parameters associated with the flavonoid biosynthesis.

subSection.paragraph: TFC: total flavonoid content, CHS: chalcone synthase, CHI: chalcone isomerase, FLS: flavonol synthase, MYB: transcription factor.

Since phenylpropanoid-derived specialized metabolites are valuable components in plant defense responses, flavonoid-based discrimination of resistant and susceptible carnation cultivars is a favorable strategy to identify these resistance-related biochemical and molecular traits. Thus, to expand the current understanding of the mechanisms underlying the inherent resistance and induced response against vascular wilting, the present study determined the early variations in the metabolite and transcriptional levels in carnation roots in response to Fod . The disease evolved faster in the susceptible variety (‘ Mizuki ’, MSC ) than in the resistant variety (‘
Golem
’, GRC ), while the accumulation of certain flavonol acylglycosides (e.g., kaempferol 3- O -(acetyl-rhamnosyl)- diglucoside ( 6 ) and kaempferol 3- O -(sinapoyl-glucosyl)-glucoside ( 11 )) in GRC was faster (48 hpi) to those in MSC (at 96 hpi), suggesting that these compounds play a defensive role (e.g., phytoanticipins, phytoalexins and/or antioxidants) against Fod . In addition, both cultivars exhibited a pathogen presence-dependent early response (12–96 hpi) based on an increase in transcriptional levels of flavonoid biosynthesis pathway-related enzymes, but GRC showed the highest expression levels of such genes faster (i.e., cmyb11 at 12 hpi, chi and chs genes at 24 hpi, and fls at 48 hpi) to promote a temporally controlled polygenic response against Fod that was oriented to favor a particular accumulation of acylglycosylated kaempferol-like flavonols at 96 hpi. However, antifungal and antioxidant evaluation and functional assays using carnation mutants will be useful to demonstrate the role of each component in this molecular and biochemical model. Our findings using the present combined metabolomics- and transcriptional-based approach confirmed that flavonoid biosynthesis is a part of the complex response related to carnation resistance to the vascular wilting caused by Fod . This constitutes valuable background information for the selection of plants for carnation breeding based on differences in flavonoids and genes conferring disease resistance.

Rooted cuttings (3-week rooting) from two commercial cultivars (‘
Golem
’ resistant ( GRC ) and ‘ Mizuki ’ susceptible (MCS)) of
Dianthus caryophyllus
L. ( Caryophyllaceae ) were used. These carnation plants were grown in Colombia and were supplied by the company Florval SAS campus QFC (Bogota´Plateu, Colombia ).
Fusarium oxysporum
f. sp dianthi ( Fod ) race 2 was isolated from susceptible plants with typical symptoms of vascular wilt. This fungal isolate was maintained in a solid potato dextrose agar (PDA) medium. The typical morphology of conidia was observed through microscopy, and the species and race were verified through molecular tools described below (Abd-elsalam et al., 2003; Chiocchetti et al., 2009 ). Inoculum was prepared in previously sterilized Czapek-Dox broth by stirring for 7 days at 25 ◦ C. Medium was diluted with sterile water to obtain a suspension with a final concentration of 1.0 × 10 6 conidia/mL.

Inoculation with a pathogenic isolate of Fod was carried out according to the previous study ( Ardila et al., 2014 ). A total of 300 rooted cuttings of each cultivar ( GRC and MSC ) were inoculated by immersion of the roots into the pathogen suspension for 20 s. Simultaneously, 300 cuttings of each cultivar were subjected to the same process using sterile water instead of conidial suspension. Under a randomized 2 × 2 × 4 × 3 experimental design (i.e., cultivars × Fod - and non-inoculated × sampling times × triplicate), cuttings were planted independently for each treatment, in a 50/50 mixture of sterilized soil and rice hulls. The inoculated and control cuttings were harvested at 12, 24, 48, and 96 h after inoculation, according to previous results describing early responses associated to resistance in this pathosystem ( Ardila et al., 2014 ). For each time, three biological replicates consisted of 25 cuttings per treatment were used. The samples were washed with water to remove soil excess, and stems and roots were separated and kept at

80 ◦ C for further analysis. Resistance levels of test cultivars were confirmed by means of an in vivo assay. Hence, 25 plants of each treatment were maintained until 7 weeks post-inoculation and disease incidence were evaluated as the severity index ( SI ) based on the 0–4 scale previously proposed ( Santos-Rodriguez et al., 2021 ) as follows: 0 = no symptomatic plant, 1 = plant with 1/3 of symptoms, 2 = plant with 2/3 of symptoms, 3 = whole plant with symptoms, 4 = plant death. SI (%) = ([Σ(Class frequency × score of rating class)]/(Total number of observations) × (maximal score of rating class)) × 100, where ‘score of rating class’ is related to the disease level based on the proposed scale, ‘class frequency’ is the number of plants showing that score, ‘total number of observations’ is the total number of plants within the experiment, and the ‘maximal score of rating class’ is 4.

Polar metabolites from controls and inoculated carnation roots were extracted from 200 mg of roots using 1 mL of 80% (v/v) methanol. The samples were crushed, sonicated for 15 min (42 Hz and 100 W) and centrifuged (12,000× g , 15 min). The supernatants were transferred to eppendorf tubes and stored in the dark at 20 ◦ C for subsequent analysis ( Ardila et al., 2013 ).

Total phenolic content (TPC) were measured using the Folin–Ciocalteu method ( Ardila et al., 2013 ) with slight modifications. Each reaction mixture contained 20 μL of the methanolic extracts and 40 μL of the Folin–Ciocalteu. After 5 min, 150 μL of 7.35% Na 2 CO 3 aqueous solution and 10 μL of deionized water was added. Reaction mixture was incubated at room temperature for 1 h, and the absorbance ( 765 nm ) was measured (Varioskan™ LUX). Results were compared to a calibration curve prepared using samples containing 0, 5, 10, 20, 40, 60 ppm of gallic acid (Sigma). TPC values were expressed as microgram of gallic acid equivalents per gram of fresh tissue, according to previous research ( Ardila et al., 2013 ).

Flavonoid content was determined using the aluminum chloride method ( Ardila et al., 2013 ). Each reaction mixture contained carnation roots extract (100 μL), 5% NaNO 2 (30 μL) and deionized water (100 μL). After 5 min, 10% AlCl 3 (60 μL) was added, and after additional 6 min at room temperature, 2 M NaOH (100 μL) was also added. Absorbance was measured at 510 nm in a Varioskan™ LUX plate reader. Absorbance units were compared to a calibration curve previously prepared using samples containing 0, 5, 10, 20, 40, 60 ppm of catechin (Sigma). TFC values were expressed as microgram of catechin equivalents per gram of fresh tissue.

paragraph.emphasis: 4.4. Reverse phase ultra-high performance liquid chromatography coupled to diode array detector and mass spectrometry (RP-UHPLC-PDA-MS) analyses

subSection.paragraph: RP-UHPLC-PDA-MS analyses were performed on an Ultra-Fast Liquid Chromatographic (UFLC) Prominence system (Shimadzu, Columbia, MD, USA ) equipped with a photodiode array detector (SPD-M20A) and coupled to a LCMS2020 mass spectrometer with quadrupole analyzer and electrospray ionization (ESI). Chromatographic separation was carried out on a C18 Kinetex® 250 × 4.60 × 2.2 μm column. Elution was conducted with a mobile phase consisting of 0.1% HCOOH in H 20 (solvent A) and 0.1% HCOOH in acetonitrile (Solvent B), which was pumped at a 0.7 mL/min flow rate and the oven temperature was set at 35 ◦ C. Gradient program was set as follows: 0% B (0–3 min), 0%–15% B (4–29 min), 15%–30% B (29–48 min), 30%–100% (48–65 min). Analysis was monitored at 330 nm . ESI was operated simultaneously in positive and negative ion modes (scan 100–2000 m /z), desolvation line temperature at 250 ◦ C, nitrogen as nebulizer gas at 1.5 L/min, drying gas at 15 L/min, and detector voltage at 1.4 kV. Additionally, RP-UHPLCESI-HRMS data were also performed on a UFLC Prominence system coupled to a Bruker MicrOToF-Q II consisting of a Quadrupole-Time of Flight (QToF) analyzer and ESI. Identical chromatographic parameters above mentioned were used. ESI was operated in negative ion mode (scan 100–1500 m /z), capillary voltage at 4.5 kV, desolvation line temperature at 400 ◦ C, nitrogen as nebulizer gas at 4 Bar, drying gas at 8 L/min, quadrupole and collision energy at 7 and 20 eV, respectively.

paragraph.emphasis:
4.4.1. Flavonoid-related feature filtering and annotation of the mostimportant
features

subSection.paragraph:
Transcriptional levels of putative genes encoding CHS, CHI, FLS, and MYB TF were evaluated according to the previous study using a relative quantification to histone ( Monroy-Mena et al., 2019 ). To obtain the RNA extracts, carnation roots were macerated using liquid nitrogen in a mortar previously washed with a DEPC (diethylpyrocarbonate) solution. Extraction was performed with 0.4 g of the macerated material using Trizol (Invitrogen) according to the supplier’ s instructions. The RNA in the samples was quantified by absorbance readings at 260 nm . The A260/A280 ratio ranged from 1.9 to 2.0. To avoid contamination with DNA, 2 μg of the total RNA sample was treated with DNase (Invitrogen) under the conditions recommended by the supplier. The synthesis of cDNA from RNA was subsequently performed using oligo dT and M-MLV reverse transcriptase (Moloney murine leukemia virus, Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’ s protocol. The transcriptional levels quantification was performed using the system SYBR® Green MasterMix IQTM, Bio-Rad. To ensure that the same amount of cDNA was used in each reaction ( 10 ng ), the cDNA amount was quantified by fluorescence (Qbit®, Invitrogen). The primers used for amplification of the chs , chi , fls , and myb11 genes are listed in Table 3 . Primers of CHS and CHI were designed according to the sequences reported previously ( Ardila et al., 2013 ). For histone was used the primers described by Monroy-Mena et al. (2019) , and for fls and myb11, primers were designed using the Genome of Carnation database (ID fls : Dca12008.1 and gen ID cmyb11 : Dca26277.1). Amplification of chs y chi genes was performed using an initial denaturation at 95 ◦ C for 10 min followed by 35 cycles at 95 ◦ C (15 s), 60 ◦ C (20 s), and 72 ◦ C (20 s) and finally 72 ◦ C (1 min). For the fls , myb11 and histone genes, a modification was made, using an initial denaturation at 95 ◦ C for 10 min followed by 35 cycles at 95 ◦ C (15 s), 59 ◦ C (20 s) and 72 ◦ C (20 s) and finally 72 ◦ C (1 min). The specificity of the products was validated by analyzing the melting curves. The analysis was performed using a C1000 Thermal cycler coupled to a Bio-Rad CFX96 real-time system. The quantification was performed by comparing the values of Ct (threshold cycle) obtained for the different treatments and those obtained by the reference gene using the following formula: ( E 1)
Δ CPtarget ( control sample )
) / ( E 2)
Δ CPref ( control sample )
, where E2 = target gen and E1 = reference gen ( Pfaffl, 2001 ).

caption.paragraph: List of sequences of the primers used for qPCR quantification.

paragraph.tableNote: a According to the previous study by Monroy-Mena et al. (2019) .

subSection.paragraph:
Statistical analysis was performed for each variable for the different treatments (n = 3). Data were expressed as means ± standard deviations (SD) or SEM. The analysis of variance and differences between means were analyzed using the Statgraphics® software version 5.1 with oneway ANOVA and Tukey test (
P
˂ 0.05
). Pearson’ s correlation ( α = 0.05 ) was done using the software IBM SPSS Statistics v22.0. Furthermore, major patterns and important features from flavonoid-related metabolic profiles were obtained and described by univariate and multivariate statistics, using unpaired parametric t -test, PCA, ASCA, MEBA and ROC approaches. These analyses were performed after recovery of the peak intensity of each m/z feature present in each of the negative mode ionization-derived total ion current (TIC) chromatograms. These HRMS features were compiled under processing of the whole set of the raw TICs with MZmine 2 ( Pluskal et al., 2010 ), through the typical steps of normalization, signal detection, deconvolution, deisotopization, filtering, alignment, and gap-filling. As mentioned above, under comparison of LC-PDA data, the flavonoid-related compounds were filtered. The resulting matrix (FIT) corresponding to the combination of Observations (i.e., samples) versus Variables (i.e., features labelled as rt/ m/z pairs) was exported to.csv format and statistically analyzed through the different modules of MetaboAnalyst 4.0 (McGill University, Quebec , Canada ).
